Title:
The root of angiosperm phylogeny inferred from duplicate
phytochrome genes.
Abstract:
Understanding the radiation of flowering plants depends
critically on positioning the root of the angiosperm tree. An analysis
of duplicate phytochrome genes (PHYA and PHYC) is used to root the
angiosperms, thereby avoiding the inclusion of highly diverged outgroup
sequences. The results unambiguously place the root near Amborella (one
species, New Caledonia), and resolve water-lilies (Nymphaeales, ~ 70
species, cosmopolitan), then Austrobaileya (one species, Australia), as
early branches. These findings bear directly on the interpretation of
morphological evolution and diversification within angiosperms.
